body_html:
Does it work if you say this?

import os.path
import tensorflow as tf
_zero_out_module = tf.load_op_library(
    tf.resource_loader.get_path_to_datafile('tensorflow/core/user_ops/zero_out.so'))
zero_out = _zero_out_module.zero_out

If not, then try adding data = ["//tensorflow/core/user_ops:zero_out.so"] to whatever Bazel py_library or py_binary rule specifies the script above.

Also another nit I would recommend is that you say name = "zero_out" rather than name = "zero_out.so". Because if you use the latter name, the shared object will probably be named "zero_out.so.so".

import os.path
import tensorflow as tf
_zero_out_module = tf.load_op_library(
    tf.resource_loader.get_path_to_datafile('tensorflow/core/user_ops/zero_out.so'))
zero_out = _zero_out_module.zero_out
If not, then try adding data = ["//tensorflow/core/user_ops:zero_out.so"] to whatever Bazel py_library or py_binary rule specifies the script above.
Also another nit I would recommend is that you say name = "zero_out" rather than name = "zero_out.so". Because if you use the latter name, the shared object will probably be named "zero_out.so.so".
body:
Does it work if you say this?

``` py
import os.path
import tensorflow as tf
_zero_out_module = tf.load_op_library(
    tf.resource_loader.get_path_to_datafile('tensorflow/core/user_ops/zero_out.so'))
zero_out = _zero_out_module.zero_out
```

If not, then try adding `data = ["//tensorflow/core/user_ops:zero_out.so"]` to whatever Bazel py_library or py_binary rule specifies the script above.

Also another nit I would recommend is that you say `name = "zero_out"` rather than `name = "zero_out.so"`. Because if you use the latter name, the shared object will probably be named "zero_out.so.so".
